target_audience.primary_persona: Developers and programmers who need a lightweight, cross-platform code editor with automatic syntax highlighting for quick file editing
secondary_personas: Technical writers editing markdown and documentation files
System administrators editing configuration files (YAML, JSON, shell scripts)
Students learning to code who want a simple, non-intimidating editor
Power users who want a fast notepad alternative with syntax highlighting
pain_points: Heavy IDEs (like VSCode/IntelliJ) take too long to start for quick edits
Built-in text editors (Notepad, TextEdit) lack syntax highlighting
Want to view/edit code files directly in the browser without installing software
Need a consistent editing experience across desktop and web
Existing browser-based editors require cloud accounts or complex setup
goals: Quickly open and edit code files with syntax highlighting
Use the same familiar interface in browser and desktop
Access files from local file system without uploading to cloud
Identify programming language automatically without manual selection
Have a minimal, distraction-free editing experience
target_audience.usage_context: Quick file editing sessions - opening a config file, making small code changes, viewing source code with highlighting. Used when full IDE is overkill. Desktop version for regular use, browser version for ad-hoc access on shared computers or when software installation isn't possible.

product_vision.one_liner: A lightweight, dual-platform notepad with automatic syntax highlighting that runs seamlessly in both browser and desktop.
product_vision.problem_statement: Developers frequently need to quickly view or edit code files, but face a choice between slow, heavyweight IDEs or basic text editors without syntax highlighting. Existing lightweight editors are often platform-specific and don't offer browser-based access.
product_vision.value_proposition: Zero-friction code editing with automatic language detection and syntax highlighting, available instantly in any modern browser or as a native desktop app - no cloud accounts, no complex setup, just fast local file editing.
success_metrics: Files up to 1MB open and display syntax highlighting within 1 second
Supports 10+ programming languages with automatic detection
Works identically in Chrome/Edge browser and Electron desktop app
Zero user configuration required for basic functionality

existing_features: File system abstraction layer (BrowserFileSystem and ElectronFileSystem adapters)
Syntax highlighting with Highlight.js (17+ languages registered)
Browser app with Open/Save/Save As functionality
Debounced live syntax highlighting during typing
Unsaved changes warning before page close
Electron main process with IPC handlers
Preview panel toggle for syntax highlighted view
known_gaps: No comprehensive test suite implemented yet
E2E verification on both platforms not completed
Browser unsupported warning UI may need polish
No error boundary handling for syntax highlighting failures
No recent files or session history
technical_debt: Test infrastructure needs setup (no test directory or test commands configured)
Build configurations for production not fully verified
Electron app packaging with electron-builder untested

alternatives: Visual Studio Code - Full-featured IDE, heavy but powerful
Sublime Text - Fast, native, but paid license for continued use
Notepad++ - Windows-only, native, no browser version
Atom (discontinued) - Was similar concept but heavier
Monaco Editor (online) - Browser-based but complex setup
CodeMirror (online) - Browser-based, library not standalone app
TextEdit/Notepad (OS built-in) - Simple but no syntax highlighting
differentiators: True dual-platform: same codebase runs in browser AND as desktop app
Zero configuration - works out of the box with auto language detection
No cloud account required - local file system access only
Lightweight startup - faster than full IDEs
Privacy-focused - files never leave local machine
Modern browser API usage (File System Access API) for native-like experience
competitive_context.market_position: Positioned as a 'lightweight middle ground' between basic text editors and full IDEs. Targets developers who want quick file editing with syntax highlighting without the overhead of a complete IDE. The dual-platform approach is unique - most alternatives are either browser-only or desktop-only.

technical: File System Access API only works in Chromium browsers (Chrome, Edge) - Firefox/Safari users need Electron version
Electron requires Node.js integration with security considerations (contextIsolation must be enabled)
Highlight.js auto-detection may be inaccurate for small code snippets
Large files (10MB+) may cause performance issues with syntax highlighting
Browser version requires HTTPS in production for File System Access API
resources: Greenfield project - building from scratch without existing codebase to leverage
No dedicated QA team - testing relies on automated tests
dependencies: Vite v5+ for browser bundling and dev server
Modern browser with File System Access API support for full browser functionality
